data.text: Contents
Introduction
Requests for disclosure of Personal Identifiable Data (PID) can be received by an organisation in a number of ways.

The disclosure request may be direct (e.g. an individual request for a copy of their own health records) or may form part of an investigation (e.g. a request for a statement by the Police). The request may be vague or imprecise and may be relevant to a claim against the organisation. The person (subject) requesting their own data or a legal representative requesting subject data does not need to give a reason for wanting access.
Requests for disclosure of PID may include but is not limited to the following:
Data Subject Access Request (DSAR).
Access to Health Records request.
Staff request via HR for access to employment record/personnel files.

Request for information from a public authority e.g. Police. (Note there is now guidance from NHSx in relation to sharing information with the Police – please refer to https://www.nhsx.nhs.uk/information-governance/guidance/sharing- information-with-the-police/ for further information.

A Data Subject Access Request is a request from an individual or their legal representative asking an organisation to provide them with information relating to that individual which is held or processed by the organisation (see 3.1 ‘Data Subject Access Request')
An Access to Health Records request is a request from an individual or their legal representative asking for all or part of an individual's health records (see Trust Access to Health Records Policy)
Employees (and former staff) may also request any employment/personnel information held on them by an organisation.

On occasion, organisations may receive requests for PID from public authorities, for example from the Police in the course of investigating a crime. In such cases, the request must be submitted via the formally agreed process for review (See section 5.6.1) to ensure it meets the lawful criteria for disclosure under the General Data Protection Regulation/Data Protection Act 2018.
General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
Under Article  (1) to (3) of the GDPR, individuals have several rights in relation to the information held about them. Access gives them the right to obtain a record in permanent form.

1.8.1  The GDPR states that individuals [Identifiable Natural Person – GDPR Article 4(1)] have a right to obtain confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and where that is the case to have access to that personal data. The Individual can access the data held about them by making a request verbally or in writing including by social media, for a copy of the

information the Trust holds about them, both in electronic format and on paper, although it is advisable to ask that the request is put in writing so it is clearly documented and can be managed efficiently. An individual can make the request to any part of your organisation and they do not have to direct it to a specific person or contact point
Freedom of Information Act 2000
Applications for information of a personal nature cannot be made under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. Please refer to the Trust Freedom of Information Policy and Procedure.
It is not uncommon for a request to mistakenly state that it is a freedom of information (FOI) request. If, in fact, it relates to the requester's personal data, you must treat it as a DSAR
Scope
This policy deals with the rights of Data Subjects whereby individuals/legal representatives can request access to their personal data.

This policy applies to all requests for access to personal data held by the Trust in either paper or electronic formats. This applies to anyone about whom the Trust holds information – including staff, former staff, patients and other service users.
Health Records Requests can be made under the Access to Medical Records Act 1990, using the Trust Policies and Procedures.
This policy provides a framework for the Trust to ensure compliance with the GDPR 2016 and Data Protection Act 2018.
Definitions

table_items.text: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) applies to both automated personal data and to manual filing systems where personal data are accessible according to specific criteria. This could include chronologically ordered sets of manual records containing personal data. Personal data that has been pseudo-anonymised – e.g. key-coded – can fall within the scope of the GDPR depending on how difficult it is to attribute the pseudonym to a particular individual.

Any information relating to an identifiable person who can be directly or indirectly identified in particular by reference to an identifier or group of identifiers. The GDPR definition provides for a wide range of personal identifiers to constitute personal data, including name, identification number, location data or online identifier, reflecting changes in technology and the way organisations collect information about people.

The GDPR refers to sensitive personal data as “special categories of personal data”. The special categories specifically include revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data where processed to uniquely identify an individual, data concerning health or data covering and individual's sex life or sexual orientation. Personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences are not included, but similar extra safeguards apply to its processing.

The living individual to whom the information refers and who can be identified from that information. All Identifiable Natural Persons have certain legal rights in relation to their personal identifiable information. Information relating to deceased individuals is governed by other legislation.

A ‘health record' is defined as being any record which consists of information relating to the physical or mental or condition of an individual, and has been made by or on behalf of a health professional in connection with the care of that individual. The definition can also apply to material held on an x-ray or an MRI scan. This means that when a data subject access request is made, the information contained in such material must be supplied to the applicant, unless there are extenuating circumstances or exemptions that prevent the information to be disclosed.

An ‘employment record' is defined as being any record which consists of information relating to a current or former member of staff and has been made by or on behalf of the Trust in connection with the individual's employment.

An ‘occupational health record' is defined as being any record which consists of information relating to the physical or mental or condition of a current or former member of staff and has been made in connection with the individual's employment.
A ‘complaint file' is defined as being any record which consists of information relating to a complaint made by a patient or a representative acting on their behalf.
An ‘incident file' is defined as being any record which consists of information relating to an incident involving a patient; employee; contractor or visitor.

data.text: Request for disclosure of PID/Data Subject Access Request (DSAR):

3.1.1 A Data Subject Access Request (DSAR) is any request made by an individual or an individual's legal representative for information held by the Trust about that individual. The Data Subject Access Request provides the right for data subjects to see or view their own personal data as well as to request copies of the data. This may include any information held about the individual such as any type of written documentation, email correspondence, personnel records, images, audio and video recordings and CCTV footage.

3.1.2 A request for disclosure of PID/Data Subject Access Request does not need to be made in writing. Verbal requests for information held about an individual are valid DSARs, and should be managed as such, although it is advisable to ask that the request is put in writing so it is clearly documented and can be managed efficiently A request does not have to include the phrases 'subject access request', ‘right of access', or ‘Article 15 of the GDPR'. It just needs to be clear that the individual is asking for their own personal data.
3.1.3 DSARs made online must be treated like any other Data Subject Access Requests when they are received, though the Trust will not provide personal information via social media channels.
3.1.4 DSARs only apply to living individuals.
Data on a deceased person is confidential however it is not covered by the Data Protection Act but instead by the Freedom of Information Act.
In deciding whether to allow access to an individual requesting information in relation to a deceased person we will need to consider any responsibility of confidentiality to that deceased person.
We should also consider the rights of the applicant and data subject under the Human Rights Act, Article 8 - the right to respect for a private and family life.
Roles and Responsibilities

Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group is responsible for the review and approval of the information governance framework, overseeing the monitoring of the information governance framework, ensuring compliance with the Data Security & Protection Toolkit requirements, and providing assurance of such for the Trust.
4.1.1  Document Management Group is to:
Provide a systematic approach across the 3 Trust sites to the development and approval of documents;
Sustain a corporate image in all documentation used throughout the 3 Trust sites.
The Chief Executive as the Trust's Accountable Officer has ultimate responsibility for compliance with legal requirements and achievement of standards of best practice and will ensure:
Appropriate delegation of risk management and confidentiality management functions to a Director or equivalent;
Adequate resources to support effective information governance;
Submission of the annual Data Security and Protection Toolkit compliance self- assessment.
4.2.1 The Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Board appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.2 The Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Director responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PID processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PID.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PID where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
Granting approval for disclosure of PID to the Police or other public authorities.
4.2.3 Clinical Directors (CD's) / Associate Clinical Directors (ACDs) / General Managers and Head Nurses – as senior leaders at each Trust they have responsibility for:
Compliance with the requirements of this policy within their local area of management.
Ensuring staff within their management remit undertake mandatory information governance and other relevant training.
Ensuring the information asset owner is aware and facilitates the disclosure of information when required.
4.2.4 Head of Information Governance/Data Protection Officer and Information Governance Manager are responsible for:

Providing advice and guidance about GDPR to work colleagues at all levels, and for maintaining a log of requests for disclosure of PID/Subject Access Requests received to ensure compliance within the legal timeframe.
Operational responsibility for development and updating of IG management frameworks and Policies in line with local and National requirements.
4.2.5 The Head of Health Records has responsibility for:
Ensuring all Data Subject Access Requests regarding health records (Access to Health Records) are actioned within the legal timeframe.
Maintaining a record of all Access to Health Records requests received.
4.2.6 The Complaints Manager has responsibility for:
Ensuring all Data Subject Access Requests regarding complaints are actioned within the mandatory one calendar month timeframe.
4.2.7 The Patient Safety/Risk/Incident Manager has responsibility for:
Ensuring all Data Subject Access Requests regarding incidents and alerts are actioned within the mandatory one calendar month timeframe.
4.2.8 The Head of Human Resources is responsible for:
Requests by employees or ex-employees for copies of their personal employment files (this includes both medical and non-medical staff) within the mandatory one calendar month timeframe.
4.2.9 The Head of Legal Services is responsible for:
Ensuring all requests received pertaining to legal cases are actioned within the legal timeframe.
4.2.10 Line Managers are responsible for:

Ensuring that all staff are aware of this policy; and the requirement to comply within the one calendar month timeframe should a request for disclosure of PID/ Data Subject Access Request be received.
Ensuring that all staff are aware of how to deal with a request for disclosure of PID/Data Subject Access Request or are provided with, or know where to obtain, further advice and guidance.
4.2.11 Trust Staff are responsible for:
Implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
Being aware of how to deal with a request for disclosure of PID /Data Subject Access Request should one be received.
Seeking further advice and guidance in the event of uncertainty when receiving a request for disclosure of PID /Data Subject Access Request.
The Rights of a Data Subject
The rights to data subject access include the following:
Know whether a data controller holds any personal data about them.
Receive a description of the data held about them and, if permissible and practical, a copy of the data.
Be informed of the purpose(s) for which that data is being processed, and from where it was received.
Be informed whether the information is being disclosed to anyone apart from the original recipient of the data; and if so, the identity of those recipients.

The right of data portability. Data subjects can ask that their personal data be transferred to them or a third party in machine readable format (Word, PDF, etc.). However, such requests can only be fulfilled if the data in question is:
1) Provided by the data subject to the Trust,
2) Is processed automatically and
3) Is processed based on consent or fulfilment of a contract.
If the data is being used to make automated decisions about the data subject, to be told what logic the system uses to make those decisions and to be able to request human intervention.
Who can make an application for personal data?
The Data Subject
A person lawfully acting on their behalf:

Legal authorities such as the Police under certain exemptions of the GDPR/DPA e.g. personal data may be processed when it is for "the prevention or detection of crime, the apprehension or prosecution of offenders…' (Schedule 2).

Where a child is competent, they are entitled to make or consent to a DSAR to access their record. Children aged over 16 years are presumed to be competent. Children under 16 in England must demonstrate that they have sufficient understanding of what is proposed in order to be entitled to make or consent to a DSAR. However, children who are aged  or over are generally expected to have the competence to give or withhold their consent to the release of information from their health records. When assessing a child's competence, it is important to explain the issues in a way that is suitable for their age. Where, in the view of the appropriate health professional, a child lacks competency to understand the nature of his or her DSAR application, the holder of the record is entitled to refuse to comply with the DSAR. Where a child is considered capable of making decisions about access to his or her medical record, the consent of the child must be sought before a parent or other third party can be given access via a DSAR
Timescales

It is important that action is taken promptly as the legislation dictates that the information requested must be provided without delay and at the latest within one month, following confirmation of identity verification and acknowledgement that specific and sufficient information has been received to assist with the request.

5.3.1 In line with ICO guidance, following receipt of a DSAR it is acceptable to request clarification about what is being requested if ‘…you are satisfied that you hold a large amount of information, and it is not clear what information the individual is requesting'. If required, clarification must be sought as soon after receipt of the initial request as possible. ICO guidance states: ‘If you process a large amount of information about an individual, you may ask them to specify the information or processing activities their request relates to before responding to the request. The time limit for responding to the request is paused until you receive clarification. This is referred to as ‘stopping the clock'. This means that you do not need to provide the individual with a copy of the information, or any of the supplementary information that you cannot reasonably provide, unless you have obtained clarification'.

5.3.2 The timescale for the period of compliance may be extended by a further two months where requests are complex or numerous. If this is the case, the individual must be informed within one month of the receipt of the request and an explanation given as to why the extension is necessary. This decision must be documented in the DSAR log.
5.3.3 Where information is requested by a legal authority such as the Police, once the request is approved the information must be provided as soon as possible.
5.3.4 The timescale for information requested via the Access to Health Records process is one calendar month.
Charges

A copy of the information requested as a DSAR must be provided free of charge. However, in line with the current UK Data Protection Act, when a request is deemed ‘manifestly unfounded or excessive', particularly if it is repetitive, a ‘reasonable fee' can be charged.
5.4.1 A reasonable fee can also be charged to comply with requests for further copies of the same information. This does not mean a charge can be applied to subsequent access requests.

5.4.2 Any fee must be based on the administrative cost of providing the information, and would be charged to the requestor at the discretion of the Data Protection Officer/Senior Information Risk Owner.
Requirements for a valid request for disclosure of PID/DSAR
In order to be able to respond to the Data Subject Access Requests in a timely manner, the data subject must:
Provide the Trust with sufficient information to validate their identity (to ensure that the person requesting the information is the data subject or his/her authorized representative).
Provide sufficient detail deemed necessary for the Trust to undertake any system searches required to locate the requested information.
Submit the relevant form in line with agreed protocol (legal authority/Police requests).
Submit the relevant form as per the Trust Access to Health Records policy.

It is recommended that staff direct individuals enquiring about how to access their personal data to the following link on the MSE Website, where they can find more information about Data Subject Access Requests including how to apply: https://www.mse.nhs.uk/information-governance-and-data-protection
(Also see Appendix 2: DSAR Application Form)

5.5.1 Subject to the exemptions referred to in this document, the Trust will provide information to requestors whose requests are made either verbally or in writing, and are received from an individual whose identity can be validated by the Trust. Where further information is needed in order for the Trust to provide the requested information, the requestor will be contacted to ascertain additional details to ensure all required information is provided.
5.5.2 Requests are more likely to be successful where they are specific and targeted at particular information, and GDPR Recital 63 permits the Trust to request further clarification.

5.5.3 Factors that can assist in narrowing the scope of a search include identifying the likely holder of the information (e.g. by making reference to a specific department), the time period in which the information was generated or processed (the narrower the time frame, the more likely a request is to succeed) and being specific about the nature of the data sought (e.g. a copy of a particular form or email records from within a particular department).

5.5.4 However, the Trust will not provide data where the resources required to identify and retrieve it would be excessively difficult or time-consuming. The Trust is obliged to provide sufficient evidence to the requestor in these cases.
Processing a request for disclosure of PID/DSAR
5.6.1 Any requests for Access to Health Records must be referred to the Access to Health Records Team for processing in line with Trust Access to Health Records policy.
5.6.2 Any requests relating to employee information must be referred to the Human Resources Department for processing.
5.6.3 Any requests for PID from the Police or other legal authorities must be escalated immediately to the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager for review/action.

5.6.4 Upon receipt of a request for disclosure of PID/DSAR, the recipient must acknowledge the request with the Data Subject immediately using the DSAR Response Letter template (see Appendix 3). If the initial request does not provide sufficient information to support the search process, clarification must be requested as soon as possible in order to narrow the scope of the search, enabling an efficient and timely response. The DSAR Response Letter template clearly sets out the terms of the process, and both the subject and Trust obligations (see ‘DSAR Response Letter' template Appendix 3).
5.6.5 The recipient should also notify the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager of the request immediately to enable this to be recorded in the Trust central DSAR log.

5.6.6 Any requests for disclosure of email correspondence must be escalated to the IG Team immediately so that approval can be obtained from either the Chief People & Organisational Development Director, or Chief Executive at the earliest opportunity prior to the search request being logged with NHS Digital Forensic Search.
For detailed instructions on how to prepare information in response to a DSAR, please see Appendix 4: ‘Data Subject Access Request: Standard Operating Procedure'
Disclosures of Information to the Police
The police may ask health and care organisations to provide them with information about
patients and service users to support their work.
There are times when this information:

Must be provided to the police because the law requires it, for example, information relating to a road traffic accident. You will usually be told of this type of sharing although this will not always be the case

May be provided to the police because a sufficiently important reason has been given by the police. An example is in relation to the prevention or detection of a serious crime such as an assault where the victim has suffered serious harm. You will usually be asked before your information is shared with the police

There are times when it is not appropriate to inform or ask patients and service users about the sharing. Examples include where doing so would undermine a police investigation or put someone or another person at risk of serious harm. Each request must be considered carefully on a case by case basis.

The public interest is best served when health and care organisations co-operate with the police. However, any decisions to disclose personal or confidential patient information must be taken on a case-by-case basis. A clear legal basis must be identified and recorded and in line with professional guidance. There are legal constraints on what can and should be provided, but this depends on the circumstances.
The following should help in the event that you are asked for information by the police:
5.7.1 Make sure you know how to get support and advice

Information requests from the Police are usually received via a “Police Request for Information Form” (see 5.7.2). If you receive an information request from the Police, please forward this immediately to the Information Governance Team. The Head of Information Governance or Information Governance Manager will review the request and liaise with the Trust Caldicott Guardian or Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO), who will decide on whether the request for disclosure is appropriate.

Once reviewed, the Head of Information Governance or Information Governance Manager will advise of the outcome of the review. If you do not hold the information that is required by the Police (i.e. the disclosure relates to part of a patient medical records), the Information Governance Team will forward the request to the Medical Records Team to disclose.

If an information request from the Police is received out-of-hours, please refer the request to the Site Management Team or senior manager for further advice and guidance. If a decision really cannot wait because someone is at imminent risk of serious harm, use your professional judgement. If in doubt, seek advice from the most senior manager on call before making a disclosure decision. You must record your reasons irrespective of whether or not you share information.

Disclosures to the police are still subject to legal redactions, such as third party information. This is unless there is a justification for disclosing that information (for example, the police can justify the requirement for the original, unredacted record).

If it is appropriate for you to respond to the police, this should be in writing. In an emergency or urgent situation, a verbal response may be provided but this should be followed up in writing as soon as possible. If you have been asked to provide information either on a CD, DVD, USB or via digital media or email, the files must be encrypted or sent from an NHSmail account to a pnn.police.uk email account. All transfers, including paper, must be to a named individual and be secure.

You should respond to police requests in a timely manner (this will vary depending on the amount of information relevant to the enquiry), or within the timeframe stipulated on a court order. If the request is going to take longer than anticipated to respond to, it is advisable to contact the police or court and explain the situation.

In some cases, the police may want to inspect the record at your premises, rather than have a copy sent. In these cases, you should agree on a time for the visit (which should be as soon as possible). Review the record ahead of the visit to ensure that you will not inadvertently disclose information that is irrelevant to police inquiries. Ideally, you should have a clinician available to help the police understand any medical terms or content that might be unfamiliar to them.

Understand that there may be times when it is appropriate to challenge a request from the police. You should not feel under pressure to provide personal or confidential patient information and never give the police an original health and care record to take away. You should use the support available in your organisation. If you have any concerns, contact the Information Governance Team or Senior Manager for advice.
5.7.2 Police Request for Information Forms (see Appendix 5):
The police force have standard forms (often referred to as A101, DP7 or DP9 - and previously known as “Section  forms”) for requesting personal or confidential patient information.
A request should be provided in writing and signed by a senior officer (usually Inspector or above like a Chief Inspector, Superintendent or Chief Superintendent).
The request should provide:

a clear indication that the police are confident that they are working within the framework of the Data Protection Act (DPA). It should satisfy all relevant DPA requirements and be clear that information is required for the prevention and detection of crime. It is important to remember that in order to rely upon a public interest justification for the disclosure of personal or confidential patient information, the police must be investigating or preventing serious crime. For example, crime where a person has or might suffer serious harm.

clarification on whether informing the individual about the disclosure would prejudice the investigation. Note, that where the request does not set the requirement to inform an individual aside, then this must be done as soon as possible and should not delay any disclosure.
a clear description of the specific information that is requested. This must match the information you have on your systems.

an outline the nature of the offence so that you can make an informed decision about whether to disclose the information and whether the crime is sufficiently serious to justify a disclosure in the public interest.
Whilst the forms can provide useful information to support decision making about disclosure, it does not enable confidentiality requirements to be set aside or overridden.

5.7.3 Make sure you know what to do if you are responsible for making a decision If you are responsible for responding to the police or making a decision about sharing information, it is important that you are prepared in advance of any request.
Decisions on providing information to the police may be:
in response to a request from the police
due to an incident which the police should be alerted to for example, reporting knife crime
When deciding whether to disclose information, there are several things to consider:
if there is a legal duty to disclose;

whether the public interest served by disclosure outweighs the public interest served by protecting the confidentiality of the individual and the public interest served by providing a confidential service to the wider public;

whether it is necessary to disclose personal or confidential patient information. If so, when. For example, you might report a suspected knife crime to the police without disclosing the details of the victim in the first instance in order to avoid delaying or hampering their treatment;

the minimum amount of data you need to share to support the police in their work. You don't need to share any clinical information. An example is if you are requested to provide a patient's contact details or you might confirm a person attended the Emergency Department without disclosing details of the treatment they received.
5.7.4 When you must provide information to the police

Where there is a legal duty to disclose, this means you MUST provide the necessary and relevant information. You should make sure that any disclosure is required by law and, if necessary, ask the police to confirm the statutory or other legal basis they are relying upon. Also, ensure any disclosure you make is consistent with the guidance published by your professional regulator.
Common examples include:

prevention of Terrorism Act (1989) and Terrorism Act (2000). You must inform the police if you have information (including personal information or confidential patient information) that may assist them in preventing an act of terrorism or help in apprehending or prosecuting a terrorist;
the Road Traffic Act (1988). You must inform the police, when asked, for any information that might identify any driver who is alleged to have committed an offence under the Act;
the Female Genital Mutilation Act (2003). You must report to the police where it appears that a girl under the age of 18 has been subject to genital mutilation.

The police sometimes get court orders to obtain information from organisations or individuals and you must comply with court orders. You should always seek advice from your Information Governance manager, senior clinical managers, Caldicott Guardian, Data Protection Officer (DPO) and/or legal advisors/medical defence organisations where a court order has been served. Where a court order is ambiguous or appears to require

disclosure of too much data, it may be possible to query it with the court. The decision to query a court order needs to be made at an appropriate level of seniority and be actioned as quickly as possible.
5.7.5 When you need to decide whether to provide information to the police
In some cases, the law provides permission for you to disclose information, but you are not obliged to do so. You therefore have to decide whether the public interest is best served by:
(i) protecting confidentiality; (ii) disclosing personal or confidential patient information or
(iii) disclosing information that does not identify a patient but may still assist the police in their inquiries (for example, the location of a violent incident).

Generally, a disclosure can be made in the public interest to assist the police in preventing or detecting a serious crime or to prevent serious harm to another person. Your regulator (for example GMC, NMC) may set out professional standards in relation to public interest disclosures which you will need to abide by.

In circumstances where you have to make a decision whether to disclose information you must take into account patient confidentiality. You should generally seek explicit consent, under common law, from the patient or service user. However, there are circumstances where this would not be appropriate. This includes where it would cause harm to the patient or service user or others. For example, if you are treating a child who may be presented with injuries that suggest potential child abuse. You would not tell the parents that you are informing the police, as this may cause the parents to abscond or flee, potentially placing the child at greater risk of physical or mental harm.
5.7.6 General points to consider when responding to any request
You should remember the following in relation to any request for information from the police:

Ask the police to provide further information, if required, to assist you in ensuring any disclosure you make is necessary and proportionate. For example, helping you identify the correct person from your organisation's records or sharing details of the incident they are investigating to help establish whether there is a public interest justification for disclosing personal or confidential patient information.

Consider whether it is appropriate to seek explicit consent from the individual before disclosing information to the police. For example, seeking consent would not put the patient or another person at risk of serious harm, or undermine a police investigation by allowing a suspect to abscond.

Only provide information that is necessary and relevant for the specific enquiry. For example, if the police want inpatient dates, only provide inpatient dates once you are satisfied with the validity of the request.
Document what was requested, by whom, what was given and obtain a signature from the requester. This can be documented in the health and care record or a log or register of disclosures.
Where time permits or you are not sure what to do, you should seek advice, for example, from the Caldicott Guardian, IG Team, medical defence organisation or Data Protection Officer.
Identity Verification

5.8.1 Upon receipt of a DSAR, the department/division must check the identity of anyone making a request for disclosure of PID/DSAR to ensure information is only given to the person who is entitled to it. If the identity of a requestor has not already been provided, the handler must ask the requestor to provide two forms of identification, one of which must be a photo identity and the other a confirmation of address.

5.8.2 If the requestor is not the data subject, written confirmation that the requestor is authorized to act on behalf of the data subject or has legal jurisdiction to access the information (e.g. POA (Power of Attorney), Police) is required.
Information for Disclosure

5.9.1  Upon receipt of the fully defined request and required identification documents, the department/division will provide the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager with all relevant information in support of the request for disclosure of PID/DSAR. Where the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager is reasonably satisfied with the information presented by the department/division responsible for collating the request, the requestor should be notified in writing that their request for disclosure of information/DSAR will be responded to within one calendar month. This period begins from the day the required documents are received. The requestor will be informed by the department/division responsible in writing if there will be any deviation from the one calendar month timeframe due to other intervening events.
Review of Information

5.10.1 The relevant department/division will be responsible for contacting the relevant department(s) (e.g. IT) and requesting the relevant information as detailed in the DSAR. This may also involve an initial meeting with the relevant department(s) to go through the request for disclosure of PID/DSAR. A date should be agreed between the involved departments for the provision of the requested information, to allow sufficient time for checking and approval prior to final submission to the requestor.

5.10.2 It is the responsibility of the department/division to which the request for disclosure of PID/DSAR relates to search for the requested information both in paper and electronic format. Searches need to be reasonable and proportionate. The relevant department/division must be able to provide evidence to show what has been done to identify/search for the Personal Identifiable Data relating to the request for disclosure of PID/DSAR. This must include searches of all relevant systems/databases including information stored off-site (if applicable), electronic and manual databases and archived records.
5.10.3 Even if an individual is identified or identifiable, directly or indirectly, from the data you hold or are processing, it is not personal data unless it ‘relates to' the individual.

5.10.4 When considering whether information ‘relates to' an individual, you must take into account a range of factors, including the content of the information, the purpose or purposes for which you are processing it, and the likely impact or effect of that processing on the individual.
5.10.5 Where there are concerns about the complexity of the request, advice should be sought from the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager.

5.10.6 The department/division which holds the information must return the required information within the previously agreed time frame, allowing sufficient time for appropriate checks e.g. ensuring that no third party Personal Identifiable Data is contained in the documentation, redacting this as required, etc. It is not acceptable to amend or delete the data if you would not otherwise have done so. Under the DPA 2018, it is an offence to make any amendment to data with the intention of preventing its disclosure.

5.10.7 A meeting can be arranged with the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager by the department/division to review the information, if required. The Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager will determine whether there is any information which may be subject to an exemption and/or if consent is required to be provided from a third party.
5.10.8. The department/division must ensure that the information is received and reviewed by the imposed deadline to ensure the one calendar month timeframe is not breached.
Response to Data Subject Access Requests

5.11.1 The department/division will provide the finalised response together with the information retrieved from the department(s) and/or a statement that the Trust does not hold the information requested, or that an exemption applies. The department/division must ensure that a written response will be sent back to the requestor. This will be via email, unless the requestor has specified another format or method by which they wish to receive the response (e.g. post). The Trust will only provide information via channels that are secure. Information must be provided to the requestor encrypted and sent via nhs.net unless they have specifically requested otherwise.
Guidance on encrypting nhs.net emails can be found here: https://digital.nhs.uk/services/nhsmail/guidance-for-sending-secure-email
When hard copies of information are requested, documents must be sealed securely and sent by recorded delivery.
5.11.2 The department/division will advise the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager of the final response, including details of the date sent, and a summary of the information sent.
5.11.3 A copy of the response and the information sent MUST be kept by the department/division in the event of any queries or issues raised by the Data Subject
or the Information Commissioner's Office.
Archiving

After the response has been sent to the requestor, the request for disclosure of PID/DSAR will be considered closed. The DSAR will be archived by the department/division responsible for collating the information in line with the NHS Records Management Code of Practice.
5.12.1 SAR Compliance Reporting/Monitoring

Compliance and Monitoring of DSARs will take place at the Risk and Compliance Committee and Information Governance Steering Group to ensure the Trust has oversight of the current DSAR position, and address any areas of potential non- compliance.
Exemptions
5.13.1 An individual does not have the right to access information recorded about someone else, unless they are an authorised representative, or have parental responsibility or legal jurisdiction.

5.13.2 The Trust is not required to respond to requests for information unless it is provided with sufficient details to enable the location of the information to be identified, and to satisfy itself as to the identity of the data subject making the request.
5.13.3 In principle, the Trust will not normally disclose the following types of information in response to a Data Subject Access Request:

Information about other people – A Data Subject Access Request may cover information which relates to an individual or individuals other than the data subject. Access to such data will not be granted, unless the individuals involved consent to the disclosure of their data.

Repeat requests – Where a similar or identical request in relation to the same data subject has previously been complied with within a reasonable time period, and where there is no significant change in personal data held in relation to that data subject, any further request made within a six-month period of the original request will be considered a repeat request, and the Trust will not normally provide a further copy of the same data. However, if a further copy of the same data is required, the Data Subject will be advised the Trust will charge a fee (See 5.4).
Publicly available information – The Trust is not required to provide copies of documents which are already in the public domain.

Opinions given in confidence or protected by copyright law – The Trust does not have to disclose personal data held in relation to a data subject that is in the form of an opinion given in confidence or protected by copyright law.

Privileged documents – Any privileged information held by Trust need not be disclosed in response to a DSAR. In general, privileged information includes any document which is confidential (e.g. a direct communication between a client and his/her lawyer) and is created for the purpose of obtaining or giving
legal advice.

Under the GDPR/DPA, there are exemptions which may permit the Trust to disclose PID to anyone other than the data subject or their legal representative, including disclosure of information in order to assist in the detection or prevention of crime.
Please refer to the Data Protection Act 2018 for full details of exemptions.
Data Subject Access Request Refusals
There are situations where individuals do not have a right to see information relating to them. For instance:

If an exemption applies, you can refuse to comply with a SAR (wholly or partly). Not all exemptions apply in the same way and you should look at each exemption carefully to see how it applies to a particular request.
You can also refuse to comply with a SAR if it is: manifestly unfounded; or manifestly excessive – for definitions, please refer to ICO Right of Access guidance.
If the information is kept only for the purpose of statistics or research, and where
the results of the statistical work or research are not made available in a form that identifies any of the individuals involved.

Requests made for other, non-data protection purposes can be rejected. 5.13.1  If the responsible person refuses a request for disclosure of PID/DSAR on behalf of the Trust, the reasons for the rejection must be clearly set out in writing. Any individual dissatisfied with the outcome of his/her Data Subject Access Request is entitled to make a request to the Data Protection Officer to review the outcome.
Responsibilities
If the Trust acts as a data controller, i.e. the Trust owns the data, in relation to the data subject making the request, then the request will be addressed based upon this policy.

5.15.1 If the Trust acts as a data processor, the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager will forward the request to the appropriate data controller on whose behalf the Company processes personal data of the data subject making the request.

data.text: Training Requirements

Annual Information Governance training is mandatory for all staff. Any staff responsible for handling requests for disclosure of PID/Data Subject Access Requests must be aware of their responsibilities in complying with Data Protection Principles and Trust Information Security policies.
Monitoring and Audit

This policy will be monitored through summary updates to the Information Governance Group (IGG) from the divisions/departments. Where requests are not managed within the agreed timescales and standard, the IGG will escalate to the Group's Joint Information Governance Steering Group.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This policy will be approved by the Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group and MSE Group Senior Information Risk Owner at least annually, unless national policy or legislation requires an earlier review. The policy will be ratified at group level by the Document Management Group.
The Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager will raise awareness of the policy through staff communication channels and in relevant meetings.

The Head of Legal Services; Complaints Manager; Patient Safety/Risk/Incident Manager, Head of Human Resources, Health Records Manager and all senior managers will ensure that requests for disclosure of PID/SARs for which they are responsible are logged via the Data Protection Officer/Information Governance Manager, and processed to meet the required timescales for completion.
All staff involved with requests must be aware of the process to ensure they respond to meet the requirements and timescales detailed in the policy.

Appendix 4: Data Subject Access Request – Standard Operating Procedure

1.1 A DSAR is a request made by or on behalf of any living individual (Data Subject), for their information. Article 15 of the UK GDPR states that Data Subjects have the right to request a copy of their Personal Data which is held by the Trust, and/or information about the Trust's processing of their Personal Data as follows:
The purposes for processing Personal Data
The categories of Personal Data being processed
Recipients/categories of recipient
Retention periods
Information about their rights
The right to complain to the ICO,
Details of the relevant safeguards where Personal Data is transferred outside the EEA
Any third-party source of the Personal Data

A Data Subject can request data held about them verbally or in writing including by social media, and submit the request to any individual or department in the Trust. The DSAR may also be submitted via the Trust DSAR application form (see Appendix 2).

If you receive a request meeting all or any of the above criteria, then it must be managed in line with the Trust DSAR policy MSEPO-19024 and this SOP. If you are uncertain as to whether the request received constitutes a DSAR, please contact the Information Governance Team for assistance.
On receipt of the DSAR, you must notify the IG Team immediately so it can be logged on the central DSAR database.
Acknowledgement of the DSAR must be sent within 3 working days of receipt using the template provided in Appendix 3 of the DSAR policy MSEPO-19024.
Prior  to  sending  the acknowledgement,  carefully  check  the  DSAR  to ensure  it contains sufficient detail for the necessary system searches to be undertaken.

A DSAR containing sufficient information would include details of what is being requested (e.g. personnel information, documents, email correspondence, audio recordings, CCTV footage, etc.), the name, address/email address and date of birth and/or other unique identifier such as NHS number, any key words /names /terms, and any key dates.

Example  A  is  a  DSAR  which  includes  sufficient  information  to  undertake  the necessary searches. An acknowledgement letter can be sent out advising that the DSAR is in progress and the Trust will provide the requested information within one calendar month.

data.text: Because the process is time-critical, it is strongly advised that the individual managing the DSAR should carefully schedule each stage of the process to factor in sufficient time for system searches to be completed, results to be provided and review and redaction work to be undertaken, as normally* the Trust has only one calendar month to provide the requested information. For example, if system searches are not requested until week 2, and the results are not returned until week 3, this does not leave reasonable time for the review and redaction work which can be very time-consuming depending on the volume and complexity of the search results.

*The Trust can extend the time to respond by a further two months if the request is complex or if we have received a number of requests from the same individual – this can include other types of requests relating to individuals' rights. For example, if an individual has made a SAR, a request for erasure and a request for data portability simultaneously. Details of complex or repeat SARs should be escalated to the IG Team.
It is imperative that searches for the requested data are undertaken as early on in the process as possible.

Once you have the information you need, a search of  all relevant databases - including hospital systems, NHSmail inboxes, and any files containing documents held electronically and/or on paper - must be initiated, for example if the request involves information held on hospital systems contact the IT Team or System Manager with all relevant detail/search criteria provided, advising that the search relates to a DSAR and must be actioned promptly. If the information requested is likely to be held on departmental drives, contact the departmental lead requesting the information as above. If the request involves email correspondence, send details of the request to the IG Team for escalation to NHS Digital (NHSD).

It is important to remember to chase up search requests to avoid any delays in the process, and to allow sufficient time for the review and redaction work, which can be time-consuming depending on the amount of information involved and the complexity of the DSAR.
All correspondence relating to the search must be saved as evidence that the Trust has made reasonable efforts to find and retrieve the requested information.

Once the IG Team have received the search results from NHSD, the files will be saved to the ‘IGSAR' folder on the MSBH_Shared (X:) drive (access to which must be authorised by the Head of IG). An email will be sent to the handler advising that the search results are in the folder. These can be accessed as follows:
Open Outlook and click on the ‘File' tab, on the top left of the ribbon menu.
Click the ‘Open & Export' option, then on ‘Open Outlook Data File' (see below)

data.url: MSEPO-19024 Data Subject Access Request (Data Disclosure) Policy.008.png

data.text: Select the ‘IGSAR' folder from the MSBH_Shared (X:) drive
Open the relevant subfolder which will contain the search results in ‘pst' files (see example below)

data.url: MSEPO-19024 Data Subject Access Request (Data Disclosure) Policy.009.png

data.text: Double-click on each file one at a time, and the results will appear as subfolders in your Outlook inbox. Each subfolder will have an arrow icon to the left of it, which will expand the search results.

Results can then be scoped to identify relevant information in line with search criteria provided. Once the scoping exercise is completed, relevant material should be transferred to the appropriate secure drive for review/redaction.
Once the relevant information has been transferred, the subfolder must be deleted from your inbox. To do this, right-click on the folder and select the ‘Close (folder name)' option.

Upon receipt of the search results, a thorough review must be carried out to ensure the information meets with the criteria provided, for example, all documents/emails are within the specified time frame cited in the DSAR.

Once you are satisfied that all the information collated is relevant to the DSAR, it must be carefully redacted to completely remove/obscure ALL personal identifiable third party information i.e. details of any individual not specifically cited in the DSAR. (Unless consent has been obtained, disclosure of third party information is a breach of  confidentiality).  The  method  of  redaction  used  depends  on  the  format  the information is provided in. If the information is provided in hard copy, it must be manually edited with a black marker, and scanned onto a secure network folder so the redacted information is not discernible. If the information is provided in Word format or can be converted into Word format (e.g. email correspondence), the information for redaction must be deleted and replaced with '(REDACTED)'..

example, in some circumstances only specific sections of particular documents may need to be disclosed. The decision on whether an exemption applies must be taken on a case-by-case basis for each individual DSAR. For more guidance on this, please contact the IG Team.

Once all the redaction work is completed, all the information must be passed on to the IG Team for final review prior to disclosure. Sufficient time should be factored in to allow for any additional redaction work identified during the review.
Unless specifically stated in the DSAR, all information provided in response to a DSAR must be sent in electronic format.

Following IG review and approval, all the information should be saved to a zip file and sent to the Data Subject with a covering email advising that the DSAR has been completed, and all relevant data identified based on the criteria has been included and that the DSAR is now closed.
